Award.AwardTitle: Non-invasive, high-resolution, 3D imaging and sensing through highly scattering materials

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project explores and develops techniques to enable high-fidelity imaging and light focusing inside and through turbid media such as biological tissue. The methods investigated are non-invasive and combine optics and acoustics. State-of-the-art high-resolution three-dimensional optical microscopy techniques have already generated a strong impact in biological and biomedical applications. Current commercial modalities include mature technologies such as confocal microscopy, two-photon microscopy, and optical coherence tomography. Unfortunately, a common shortcoming is the limited penetration into biological tissue beyond a fraction of 1 mm, the problem at the core of this proposal. High-resolution deep imaging in tissue would enable numerous biomedical research and diagnosis tools such as imaging of blood oxygenation or improving photodynamic therapy. The research will create opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students to join in collaborative interdisciplinary projects associated with this proposal. The project will also enable broad educational activities in biomedical optical imaging.

Recent advances in adaptive wavefront shaping have made imaging through scattering environments a possibility. By pre-compensating the optical wavefront, light propagation can be controlled through and beyond scattering materials. Most existing techniques, however, are limited by their need to generate a feedback signal from behind or inside the scattering media with direct invasive access, something not possible in the majority of biomedical imaging scenarios. This project emphasizes fundamental developments that address the need for deep, high-resolution imaging and focusing to tackle emerging applications. The photoacoustic effect, where acoustic waves are generated in response to an optical field, offers a new feedback mechanism for wavefront optimization because acoustic waves propagate in tissue with little scattering. Hence by detecting the acoustic waves at the surface of the scattering media, an effective and noninvasive feedback signal is obtained to guide wavefront compensation. Furthermore, the spatially nonuniform sensitivity of the acoustic transducer can be used to guide the light to a point that is substantially smaller than the acoustic focal region. Nevertheless, optical focusing and imaging through and within real biological materials remains a challenge due to the fast rate of change of the speckle field from blood flow and physiological motion and the fact that the speckle size deep in biological tissue is on the order of a wavelength. In this project, fundamental and experimental limitations on focusing in scattering media will be explored, algorithms for wavefront compensation will be optimized for focusing speed and fluence enhancement, and hardware developments for implementing wavefront compensation at speeds sufficient to overcome speckle decorrelation in biological media will be investigated.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Wave-front shaping is a powerful technique to focus light through scattering or turbid media. This is of critical importance in tissue imaging. Wave-front shaping generally requires a feedback mechanism to provide information about the light distribution behind the turbid medium and a light modulation device to shape the waves. This project has significantly advanced our knowledge and techniques to improve both of these important aspects.

Photoacoustic signals provide a noninvasive mechanism for feedback. In this technique, an ultrasound transducer is used to capture information about the absorbed light behind the turbid medium. Unfortunately, the localization of light that can be achieved using this feedback is limited by the spatial extent of the acoustic waves.  In this project, by focusing on dynamic absorbers and using the fluctuations in the photoacoustic response we succeeded in significantly reducing the size of the optical focus.

In addition to the photoacoustic feedback, fluorescence feedback is attractive in microscopy. We have demonstrated a method to focus through turbid media using fluorescence light as feedback without access to the distal side. The advantage of this method is that it allows focusing on the whole field of view without affecting the sample, making it suitable for reflection epi-illumination microscopy behind turbid layers.

Furthermore, this project explored system approaches to speed up the response time of wave-front modulation to address the fast characteristic biological time scales. We tested a new type of micro-electro-mechanical modulation system to project 350,000 patterns per second, more than one order of magnitude faster than any other existing method and 1000 times faster than the widely used liquid crystal spatial light modulators.

These results bring closer to reality the use of light to image, with high resolution, deep inside the body of living animals.
